newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Seoul shares end flat as biggest-ever strikes loom.
newsitem.headline: Seoul shares end flat as biggest-ever strikes loom.

text.p: Stocks ended Monday's trading at the previous day's closing level as fears over strikes matched improving sentiment from falling margin loans, brokers said.
South Korea is faced with the biggest strikes ever on Wednesday when the nation's two main union umbrella groups plan to call out an all-out strike in protest at a new labour law.
The composite index ended flat at a provisional 659.54 after having fluctuated from 655.74 to 664.95.
"Strikes kept bothering investors, but many people refrained from panicking on hopes that a last-minute solution could be reached," said Park Byung-moon of LG Securities.
Brokers said investors are expecting a correction early this week following the past four consecutive days of rally.
The recent rises were led by bank and other financial shares on speculation that mergers and acquisitions would be active in line with the proposed plan to restructure the industry.
"Bank and securities house stocks were the first targets for correction as they were first to spark the rally," said Yoo Nam-gil, an analyst at Hyundai Securities.
The financial sector sub-index shed 1.33 percent, or 8.47 points, to 629.14.

The speculation followed President Kim Young-sam's remarks early last week that a special panel would be established soon to oversee restructuring of the financial industry. But details have yet to be drawn up.
Brokers said outstanding margin loans owed to brokerage houses have been falling while customer deposits started increasing last week.
"The narrowing gap between margin loans and customer deposits is a very positive sign. But the possibility of strikes is blocking the improvement from being realised," said Yoo of Hyundai Securities.
Margin loans fell to 2.59 trillion won from about 2.8 trillion won late last year while customer deposits increased to 2.57 trillion won from around 2.4 trillion won, brokers said.
The nationwide strikes have crippled much of South Korean industry in protest at the forced parliamentary passage of a new labour law on December 26.

The outlawed Korean Confederation of Trade Unions has said its 500,000 members would go on an all-out strike from Wednesday if the law was not scrapped. That coincides with a call by the 1.2 million-strong Federation of Korean Trade Unions to strike on Tuesday and Wednesday. --YOO CHOON-SIK (822) 727 5646
